text: it's time to be scared which may not be
so hard these days but if you need a
little extra fright you couldn't do much
better than Night of the Living Dead a
1968 film directed by George Romero it's
now 40 years old but it's lost very
little of its freshness and over the
years it's really gained a lot of
stature and influence it really set the
tone for the kind of low-budget intense
immediate stripped-down horror
filmmaking that would come to dominate
the 1970s there's no one late you've got
nothing the movie begins in what I think
is one of the great opening sequences of
all time in a cemetery where a brother
and a sister have come to pay their
respects to a dead relative and they're
set upon by a lone kind of clumsy
awkward looking zombie zombie makes
short work of the brother and pursues
the sister to what looks like an
abandoned farmhouse in the middle of
nowhere
it turns out that she's not alone in
this house with her six other people a
family of three a young couple and a man
named Ben when it seems like the only
person with some idea of what he might
be doing why don't you see if you can
find some wood some boards something
there by the fireplace something we can
nail this place up as you might expect
some tensions erupt among these people
as they try to figure out the best way
to hold off the zombie see over the
years
zombies have really become kind of
cultural archetypes in America if you're
a liberal you might imagine that the
zombies represent brainwashed
Republicans trying to impose conformity
on everyone they see or if you're a
conservative you might imagine that the
zombies represent the forces of
political correctness trying to suppress
every expression of individuality it
doesn't really matter
the zombies are them and we're us but
I'd also note that Night of the Living
Dead sinks its teeth into a very real
and very persistent social division and
it asks a question that was pertinent in
1968 and may still be today who can we
trust who are we willing to trust
